documentation/rstools.title: Developing Riverscapes Tools
documentation/rstools.description: The following video provides a brief overview of the Riverscapes Tools development process. This uses GitHub Code Spaces to code and run the tools in the cloud. The advantage of this approach is that you are guaranteed to have a working development that comes with the correct versions of all the dependencies. These depdencies are also the identical versions used by Cyber Castor to run the tools in batches.

MIGRATED/Data_Warehouses/gettingaround.title: Getting Data from Warehouse
MIGRATED/Data_Warehouses/gettingaround.description: Once you have a  Riverscapes Wareshouse account , you can download projects and view them with RAVE.

MIGRATED/Data_Warehouses/index.title: Riverscapes Warehouse
MIGRATED/Data_Warehouses/index.description: The Riverscapes Consortium organizes and serves data via a  data warehouse . The data warehouse provides access to both the underlying data (packaged in riverscapes projects) as well as making these data explorable via a  warehouse explorer or interactive web maps. We only serve and host data packaged in fully  Riverscapes-Compliant   Riverscapes Projects .

MIGRATED/Data_Warehouses/signup.title: Riverscapes Consortium Account
MIGRATED/Data_Warehouses/signup.description: To get data from the Riverscapes Warehouse, you need to create an account or connect your Google Account.

MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.title: XML Validation
MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.description: Riverscapes relies on several different Extensible Markup Language (XML) files. They are used to define the individual projects, the data warehouses that store these projects and also how the projects are displayed in RAVE.

MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.title: Source Code Documentation
MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.description: Riverscapes tools are public and intended to be used by a broad variety of users. Therefore it is vital that the source code is logically organized and well documented.

MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.title: Automated Bibliographies
MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.description: These instructions describe how to automate a bibliography within your website using the free Zotero bibliographic software. It is possible to maintain a private or shared library within Zotero and then use the Python script on this page to export the citations to a text file for inclusion in your web site.

MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.title: Tool Web Sites
MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.description: Every riverscapes tool (piece of software) is documented using its own web site. These sites use a consistent design and content. They are intended to help end users discover, obtain and run the tools. The web sites are written as plain text markdown files stored in a GitHub repository. GitHub then handles serving these files as a web site.

MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.title: Testing Sites Locally
MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.description: It's always a good idea to verify changes locally before pushing them to GitHub. This avoids potentially breaking a site, or having to a push simply to visualize your work (only to realize a minor typo and then stage-commit-push a second time). To do this you need to run Jekyll locally on your computer and then point your browser at your localhost. Unfortunately Jekyll is coded in Ruby which can be tricky to install on Windows. Follow these one-time set-up instructions then at the bottom, the new command for running a Jekyll site from your computer:

MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.title: Theming a Tool Web Site
MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.description: We have developed a single theme that controls the look and feel of sites related to riverscapes. It's the theme that's applied to this site. If you have a Riverscapes site that doesn't look like this page or is missing page elements used on this site, then you need to follow the instructions below.

MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.title: Writing Content
MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/Docum.description: This page contains techniques for enhancing web sites stored on GitHub. GitHub uses Jekyll to take a set of documents written in markdown and publish them as a full blown web site. What follows are several tricks, techniques and patterns for enhancing these Jekyll web sites with features that make the web sites more useful. For example, adding a table of contents or injecting a page header.

MIGRATED/Tools/Technical_Reference/video.description: Posts and videos from @philpbaileynar  to help you getting started with Visual Studio Code.

MIGRATED/Tools/valueproposition.title: Value Proposition for Tool Developers and Researchers
MIGRATED/Tools/valueproposition.description: One of the realities of most academic research in the riverscape sciences is investigators are rarely rewarded or funded for doing a better job on development of their ideas. Although we are frequently encouraged to articualte (or speculate) about the significance of our research and ideas and what their impact could be to broader audiences and application, most entities funding research rarely pay for proper deployment. Some researchers will argue that "deployment is not my job" or "my ideas are so good, someone else will take them and deploy them". Those same researchers frequently complain why their great ideas are not having broader impact.
